div.p: THE MEDALL. A SATYRE AGAINST SEDITION.
By the Authour of Abalom and Achitophel.

Per Graiùm populos, mediae
que per Elidis rbem Ibat ovans; Divumque ibi pocebat Honores.

div.head: EPISTLE To the WHIGS.
div.p:
FOR to whom can I dedicate this Poem, with o much jutice as to you? 'Tis the repreentation of your own Heroe: 'tis the Picture drawen at length, which you admire and prize o much in little. None of your Ornaments are wanting; neither the Landcap of the Tower, nor the Riing Sun; nor the Anno Domini of your New Soveraign's Goronation. This mut needs be a gratefull undertaking to your whole Party: epecially to thoe who have not been o happy as to purchae the Original. I hear the Graver has made a good Market of it: all his Kings are bought up already; or the value of the remainder o inhanc'd, that many a poor Polander who would be glad to worhip the Image, is not able to go to the cot of him: But mut be content to ee him here. I mut confes I am no great Artit; but Sign-pot painting will erve the turn to remember a Friend by; epecially when better is not to be had. Yet for your comfort the lineaments are true: and though he ate not five times to me, as he did to B. yet I have conulted Hitory; as Italian Painters do, when they wou'd draw a Nero or a Caligula; though they have not een the Man; they can help their Imagination by a Statue of him, and find out the Colouring from S ••• onius and Tacitus. Truth is, you might have par'd one ide of your Medall: the Head wou'd be een to more advantage, if it were plac'd on a Spike of the Tower; a little nearer to the Sun.
Which wou'd then break out to better purpoe. You tell us in your Preface to the No-protetant Plot, that you hall be forc'd hereafter to leave off your Modetie: I uppoe you mean that little which is left you: for it was morn to rags when you put out this Medall. Never was there practis'd uch a piece of notorious Impudence in the face of an Etablih'd Government. I believe, when he is dead, you will wear him in Thumb-Rings, as the Turks did Scanderbeg; as if there were vertue in his Bones to preerve you againt Monarchie. Yet all this while you pretend not only zeal for the Publick good; but a due veneration for the peron of the King. But all men who can ee an inch before them, may eaily detect thoe gros fallacies. That it is necearie for men in your circumtances to pretend both, is granted you: for without them there could be no ground to raie a Faction. But I would ask you one civil quetion, what right has any man among you, or any Aociation of men, (to come nearer to you) who out of Parliament, cannot be conider'd in a publick Capacity, to meet, as you daily doe, in Factious Clubs, to vilify the Government in your Dicoures, and to libel it in all your Writings? who made you Judges in Irael? or how is it conitent with your Zeal of the publick welfare, to promote Sedition? Does your definition of loyal, which is to erve the King according to the Laws, allow you the licence of traducing the Executive Power, with which you own he is inveted? You complain that his Majetie has lot the love and confidence of his People: and by your very urging it, you endeavour what, in you lies, to make him loe them. All good Subjects abhor the thought of Arbitrary Power, whether it be in one or many: if you were the Patriots you would eem, you would not at this rate incene the Multitude to aume it: for no ober man can fear it, either from the King's Dipoition, or his Practice: or even, where you would odiouly lay it, from his Miniters. Give us leave to enjoy the Government and the benefit of Laws under which we were born, and which we deire to tranmit to our Poterity. You are not the Trutees of the publick Liberty: and if you have not right to petition in a Crowd, much les have you to intermeddle in the management of Affairs:
or to arraign what you do not like: which in effect is every thing that is done by the King and Council. Can you imagine that any reaonable man will believe you repect the peron of his Majety, when 'tis apparent that your Seditious Pamphlets are tuff'd with particular Reflexions on him? If you have the confidence to deny this, 'tis eay to be evinc'd from a thouand Paages, which I only forbear to quote, becaue I deire they hould die and be forgotten. I bave perus'd many of your Papers: and to how you that I have, the third part of your No-ptotetant Plot is much of it tolen, from your dead Author's Pamphlet call'd, the Growth of Popery: as manifetly as Milton's defence of the Englih People, is from Buchanan, de jure regni apud Scotos: or your firt Covenant, and new Aociation, from the holy League of the French Guiards. Any one who reads Davila, may trace your Practices all along. There were the ame pretences for Reformation, and Loyalty, the ame Aperions of the King, and the ame grounds of a Rebellion. I know not whether you will take the Hitorian's word, who ays it was reported, that Poltrot a Hugonot, murther'd Francis Duke of Guie by the intigations of Theodore Beza: or that it was a Hugonot Miniter, otherwie call'd a Presbyterian (for our Church abhors o devilih a Tenent) who firt writ a Treatie of the lawfulnes of depoing and murthering Kings, of a different Perwaion in Religion: But I am able to prove from the Doctrine of Calvin, and Principles of Buchanan, that they et the People above the Magitrate: which if I mitake not, is your own Fundamental: and which carries your Loyalty no further than your likeing. When a Vote of the Houe of Commons goes on your ide, you are as ready to oberve it, as if it were pas'd into a Law: But when you are pinch'd with any former, and yet unrepealed Act of Paliament, you declare that in ome caes, you will not be oblig'd by it. The Pasage is in the ame third part of the No-protetant Plot: & is too plain to be denied. The late Copy of your intended Aociation, you neither wholly jutify nor condemn; But, as the Papits, when they are unoppos'd, fly out into all the Pageantry's of Worhip; but in times of War, when they are hard pres'd by Arguments,
lie clos intrinch'd behind the Council of Trent: So, now, when your Affairs are in a low condition, you dare not pretend that to be a legal Combination, but whenoever you are afloat, I doubt not but it will be maintain'd and jutify'd to purpoe. For indeed there is nothing to defend it but the Sword: 'tis the proper time to ay any thing, when men have all things in their power.

In the mean time you wou'd fain be nibbling at a parallel betwixt this Aociation, and that in the time of Queen Elizabeth. But there is this mall difference betwixt them, that the ends of the one are directly oppoite to the other: one with the Queens approbation, and conjunction, as head of it: the other without either the conent, or knowledge of the King, againt whoe Authority it is manifetly deigned. Therefore you do well to have recoure to your lat Evaion, that it was contriv'd by your Enemies, and huffled into the Papers that were eiz'd: which yet you ee the Nation is not o eay to believe as your own Jury; But the matter is not difficult, to find twelve men in New-gate, who wou'd acquit a Malefactour.

I have one onely favour to deire of you at parting, that when you think of anwering this Poem, you wou'd employ the ame Pens againt it, who have combated with o much ucces againt Abalom and Achitophel: for then you may aure your elves of a clear Victory, without the leat reply. Raile at me abundantly; and, not to break a Cutome, doe it without wit: By this method you will gain a coniderable point, which is wholly to wave the anwer of my Arguments. Never own the botome of your Principles, for fear they hou'd be Treaon. Fall everly on the micarriages of Government for if candal be not allow'd, you are no freeborn ubjects. If God has not ble'd you with the Talent of Rhiming, make ue of my poor Stock and welcom: let your Veres run upon my feet: and for the utmot refuge of notorious Block-heads, reduc'd to the lat extremity of ene, turn my own lines upon me, and in utter depaire of your own Satyre, make me Satyrize my elf. Some of you have been driven to this Bay alreadie; But above all the ret commend me to the Nonconformit Paron, who writ the VVhip and Key. I am afraid it is
not read o much as the Piece deerves becaue the Bookeller is every week crying help at the end of his Gazette, to get it off. You ee I am charitable enough to doe him a kindnes, that it may be publih'd as well as printed; and that o much skill in Hebrew Derivations, ma not lie for wat-paper in the Shop. Yet I half upect he went no farther for his learning, than the Index of Hebrew Names and Etymologies, which is printed at the end of ome Englih Bibles. If Achitophel ignify the Brother of a Fool, the Author of that Poem will pas with his Readers for the next of kin; perhaps' tis the Relation that makes the kindnes. Whatever the Veres are; buy 'em up I beeech you out of pity; for I hear the Conventicle is hut up, and the Brother of Achitophel out of ervice.

Now Footmen, you know, have the generoitie to make a Pure, for a member of their Society, who has had his Livery pull'd over his Ears: and even Protestant Socks are bought up among you, out of veneration to the name. A Dienter in Poetry from Sene and Englih, will make as good a Protetant Rhymer, as a Dienter from the Church of England a Protetant Paron. Beides if you encourage ayoung Beginner, who knows but he may elevate his tilea little, above the vulgar Epithets of prophane, and awcy Jack, and Atheitick Scribler, with which he treats me, when the fit of Enthuiam is trong upon him: by which well-mannerd and charitable Expresions, I was certain of his Sect, before I knew his name. What wou'd you have more of a man? he has damn'd me in your Caue from Geneis to the Revelations: And has half the Texts of both the Tetaments againt me, if you will be o civil to your elves as to take him for your interpreter; and not to take them for Irih Witnees. After all, perhaps you will tell me, that you retain'd him only for the opening of your Caue, and that your main Lawyer is yet behind. Now if it o happen he meet with no more reply than his Predecesours, you may either conclude, that I trut to the goodnes of my Caue, or fear my Adverary or didain him, or what you pleae, for the hort on't is, 'tis indifferent to your humble ervant, whatever your Party ays or thinks of him.

div.head: UPON THE AUTHOUR of the following POEM
div.l: ONCE more our awfull Poet Arms, t'engage
The threatning Hydra-Faction of the Age:
Once more prepares his dreadful Pen to wield,
And ev'ry Mue attends him to the Field:
By Art and Nature for this Task deign'd,
Yet modetly the Fight He long declin'd;
Forbore the Torrent of his Vere to pour,
Nor loos'd his Satyre till the needful Hour:
His Sov'raigns Right by Patience half betray'd,
VVak'd his Avenging Genius to it's Aid.
Blet Mue, whoe VVit with uch a Caue was Crown'd,
And blet the Caue that uch a Champion found.
VVith choen Vere upon the Foe he falls,
And black Sedition in each Quarter galls;
Yet, like a Prince with Subjects forc't t'engage,
Secure of Conquet He rebates his Rage:
His Fury not without Ditinction heds.
Hurls mortal Bolts but on devoted Heads:
To les infected Members gentle found,
Or pares or ele pours Balm into the VVound.
Such gen'rous Grace th' ingrateful Tribe abue,
And trepas on the Mercy of his Mue;
Their wretched dogrell Rhymers forth they bring
To Snarl and Bark againt the Poet's King:
A Crew, that candalize the Nation more
Than all their Treaon-canting Priets before!
On thee He carce vouchafes a cornful mile,
But on their Pow'rful Patrons turns his Stile.
A Stile o keen as ev'n from Faction draws
The Vital Poyon, tabs to th' Heart their Caue.
Take then, great Bard, what Tribute we can raie:
Accept our Thanks, for you trancend our Praie.

div.head: To the Unknown Authour of the following Poem, and that of Abalom and Achitophel.

lg.l: THUS pious ignorance, with dubious praie,
Altars of old to Gods unknown did raie;
They knew not the lov'd Deity, they knew
Divine effects a caue Divine did hew;
Nor can we doubt, when uch thee Numbers are,
Such is their caue, tho the wort Mue hall dare
Their acred worth in humble Vere declare.
As gentle Thames charm'd with thy tuneful Song
Glides in a peaceful Majety along,
No rebell Stone, no lofty Bank does brave
The eaie paage of his ilent wave,
So acred Poet, o thy Numbers flow,
Sinewy, yet mild as happy Lovers woe;
Strong, yet harmonious too as Planets move,
Yet oft as Down upon the Wings of Love.
How weet do's Vertue in your dres appear,
How much more charming, when much les evere
Whilt you our enes harmlesly beguile,
With all th' allurements of your happy Stile,
Y' ininuate Loyalty with kind deceit,
And into ence th' unthinking Many cheat:
So the weet Trhacian with his charming lyre
Into rude Nature virtue did inpire,
So he the avage herd to reaon drew,
Yet carce o weet, o charmingly as you,
O that you would with ome uch powerful Charm
Enervate Albion to jut valour warm!
Whether much uffering Charles hall Theam afford
Or the great Deeds of God-like James's Sword,
Again fair Gallià might be ours, again
Another Fleet might Pas the ubject main.

Another Edward
• ead the Britains o • ,
Or uch an Oory as you did moan;
While in uch Numbers you, in uch a train
Inflame their courage, and reward their pain.
Let fale Achitophel the rout engage,
Talk eaie Abalom to rebel rage;
Let frugal Shimei cure in holy Zeal,
Or modet Corah more new Plots reveal,
Whilt contant to himelf, ecure of fate,
Good David till maintains the Royal State,
Tho each in vain uch various ills employs,
Firmly he tands and even thoe ills enjoys;
Firm as fair Albion midt the raging Main
Surveys encircling danger with didain.
In vain the waves aault the unmov'd hore,
In vain the winds with mingled fury rore.
Fair Albiòn's beaureous Cliffs hine whiter than before.
Nor halt thou move, tho Hell thy fall conpire,
Tho the wore rage of zeal's Fanatick Fire,
Thou bet, thou greatet of the Britih race,
Thou only fit to fill Great Charles's his place.
Ah wratched Britains: ah too tubborn Ile,
Ah tiff-neck't Irael on blet Canaan's, oyl
Are thoe dear proofs of Heaven's Indulgence vain,
Retoring David and his gentle raign.
Is it in vain thou all the Goods dot know
Aupicious Stars on Mortals hed below
VVhile all thy treams with Milk, thy Lands with Honey flow
No more fond Isle, no more they elf engage,
In civil fury, and intetine rage;
No rebel zeal thy duteous Land molet,
But a mooth Calm ooth every peacefull breat,
While in uch Charming notes Divinely ings,
The bet of Poets, of the bet of Kings,

div.head: The Medall. A SATYRE AGAINST SEDITION

lg.l: OF all our Antick Sights, and Pageantry
Which Englih Ideots run in crowds to ee,
The Polih Medall bears the prize alone:
A Monter, more the Favourite of the Town
Than either Fayrs or Theatres have hown
Never did Art o well with Nature trive;
Nor ever Idol eem'd o much alive:
So like the Man; o golden to the ight,
So bae within, o counterfeit and light.
One ide is fill'd with Title and with Face,
And, let the King hou'd want a regal Place,
On the revere, a Tow'r the Town urveys,
O'er which our mounting Sun his beams diplays,
The Word, pronounc'd aloud by Shrieval voice,
Laetamur which, in Polih, is rejoice,
The Day, Month, Year, to the great Act are join'd
And a new Canting Holiday deign'd.
Five daies he ate, for everie cat and look,
Four more than God to finih Adam took.
But who can tell what Eence Angels are,
Or how long Heav'n was making Lucifer?
Oh, cou'd the Style that copy'd every grace,
And plough'd uch furrows for an Eunuch face,
Cou'd it have form'd his ever-changing will
The various Piece had tir'd the Graver's Skill!
A Martial Heroe firt, with early care,
Blown, like a Pigmee by the VVinds, to war.
A beardles Chief, a Rebel, e'r a Man,
(So young his hatred to his Prince began)
Next this, (How wildly will Ambition teer.)
A Vermin wriggling in the th' Uurper's Ear.
Bart'ring his venal wit for ums of gold
He cat himelf into the Saint-like mould;
Groan'd, igh'd and pray'd, while Godlines was gain
The lowdet Bagpipe of the queaking Train
But, as 'tis hard to cheat a Juggler's eyes,
His open lewdnes he cou'd ne'er diguie.
There plit the Saint: for Hypocritique zeal
Allows no Sins but thoe it can conceal.
Whoring to candal gives too large a cope:
Saints mut not trade, but they may interlope.
Th' ungodly Principle was all the ame;
But a gros Cheat betrays his Partner's Game.
Beides, their pace was formal, grave and lack
His nimble Wit outran the heavy Pack.
Yet till he found his Fortune at a tay
Whole droves of Block heads choaking up his way;
They took, but not rewarded, his advice,
Villain and Wit exact a double price.
Pow'r was his aym: but, thrown from that pretence,
The wretch turn'd loyal in his own defence,
And Malice reconcil'd him to his Prince.
Him, in the anguih of his Soul he erv'd,
Rewarded fater till than he deerv'd
Behold him now exalted into trut,
His Counel's oft convenient, eldom jut.
Ev'n in the mot incere advice he gave
He had a grudging till to be a Knave.
The Frauds he learnt in his Fanatique years
Made him uneay in his lawful gears.
At bet as little honet as he cou'd.
And, like white Witches, michievouly good
To his firt byas, longingly he leans,
And rather wou'd be great by wicked means.
Thus, fram'd for ill, he loos'd our Triple hold.
(Advice unafe, precipitous, and bold.)
From hence thoe tears! that Ilium of our woe!
Who helps a powr'ful Friend, fore-arms a Foe
What wonder if the waves prevail o far
VVhen He cut down the Banks that made the bar?
Seas follow but their Nature to invade.
But He by Art our native Strength betray'd
So Sampon to his Foe his force confet.
And, to be horn, lay lumb'ring on her breat
But, when this fatal Counel, found too late,
Expos'd its Authour to the publique hate.
When his jut Sovereign, by no impious way,
Cou'd be educ'd to Arbitrary way.
Foraken of that hope. he hifts the ayle:
Drives down the Current with a pop'lar gale.
And hews the Fiend confes'd without a vaile.
He preaches to the Crowd, that Pow'r is lent,
But not convey'd to Kingly Government.
That Claimes ucceive bear no binding force.
That Coronation Oaths are things of coure.
Maintains the Multitude can never err.
And ets the People in the Papal Chair.
The reaon's obvious; Int'ret never lyes
The mot have till their Int'ret in their eyes,
The pow'r is alwaies theirs, and pow'r is ever wie,
Almighty Crowd, thou horten't all dipute,
Pow'r is thy Eence, Wit thy Attribute.
Nor Faith nor Reaon make thee at a tay,
Thou leapt o'r all eternal truths, in thy Pinbarique way.
Athens, no doubt, did righteouslie decide,
Whem Phocion and when Socrates were try'd:
As righteouslie they did thoe dooms repent,
Still they were wie, what ever way they went.
Crowds err not, though to both extremes they run,
To kill the Father, and recall the Son.
Some think the Fools were mot, as times went then
But now the World's o'r tock'd with prudentmen.
The common Cry is ev'n Religion's Tet,
The Turk's is, at Contantinople, bet,
Idols in India, Poperie at Rome,
And our own Worhip onelie true at home.
And true, but for the time, 'tis hard to know
How long we pleae it hall continue o.
This ide to day, and that to morrow burns,
So all are God-a'mighties in their turns.
A Tempting Doctrine, plauible and new:
What Fools our Fathers were, if this be true.
Who, to detroy the eeds of Civil War,
Inherent right in Monarchs did declare:
And, that a lawful Pow'r might never ceae.
Secur'd Succeion, to ecure our Peace.
Thus, Property and Soveraign Sway, at lat
In equal Balances were jutly cat
But this new Jehu purs the hot mouth'd hore,
Int • ucts the Beat to know his native force,
To take the Bit between his teeth and fly
To the next headlong Steep of Anarchy.
Too happie England, if our good we knew,
Wou'd we poes the freedom we purue,
The lavih Government can give no more:
Yet we repine, and plenty makes us poor.
God try'd us once, our Rebel-fathers fought,
He glutted'em with all the pow'r they ought,
Till, mater'd by their own uurping Brave,
The free-born Subject unk into a slave.
We loath our Manna, and we long for Quails.
Ah, what is man, when his own wih prevails.
How rah, how wift to plunge himelf in ill,
Proud of his pow'r, and boundles in his Will:
That Kings can doe no wrong we mut believe,
None can they doe, and mut they all receive.
Help heaven. or adlie we hall ee an hour,
When neither wrong nor right are in their pow'r
Alreadie they have lot their bet defence,
The benefit of Laws, which they dipence
No jutice to their righteous Caue allow'd;
But baffled by an Arbitrarie Crowd.
And Medalls grav'd, their Conquet to record,
The Stamp and Coyn of their adopted Lord
The Man who laugh'd but once, to ee an As
Mumbling to make the cros-grain'd Thitles pas,
Might laugh again, to ee a Jurie chaw
The prickles of unpalatable Law.
The witnees, that, Leech-like, liv'd on bloud,
Sucking for them were med'cinallie good,
But, when they faten'd on their feter'd Sore,
Then, Jutice and Religion they forwore,
Their Mayden Oaths debauch'd into a whore.
Thus Men are rais'd by Factions, and decry'd,
And Rogue and Saint ditinguih'd by their Side.
They rack ev'n Scripture to confes their Caue,
And plead a Call to preach, in pight of Laws.
But that's • o news to the poor injur'd Page:
It has been us'd as ill in every Age:
And is contrain'd, with patience, all to take;
For what defence can Greek and Hebrew make?
Happy who can this talking Trumpet eize;
They make it peak whatever Sene they pleae!
'Twas fram'd, at firt, our Oracle t' enquire:
But, ince our Sects in prophecy grow higher,
The Text inpires not them; but they the Text inpire.
London, thou great Emporium of our Ile,
O, thou too bounteous, thou too fruitful Nile,
How hal I praie or cure to thy deert!
Or eparate thy ound, from thy corrupted part!
I call'd thee Nile; the parallel will tand:
Thy tydes of wealth o'rflow the fattend Land;
Yet Monters from thy large increae we find;
Engender'd on the Slyme thou leav't behind.
Sedition has not wholly eiz'd on thee;
Thy nobler Parts are from infection free.
Of Irael's Tribes thou hat a numerous band!
But till the Canaanite is in the Land.
Thy military Chiefs are brave and true:
Nor are thy diinchanted Burghers few.
The Head is loyal which thy Heart commands:
But what's a Head with two uch gouty Hands?
The wie and wealthy love the uret way:
And are content to thrive and to obey.
But Wiedom is to Sloath too great a Slave,
None are o buy as the Fool and Knave.
Thoe let me cure what vengeance will they urge,
Whoe Ordures neither Plague nor Fire can purge:
Nor harp Experience can to duty bring,
Nor angry Heav'n, nor a forgiving King!
In Gopel phraze their Chapmen they betray:
Their Shops are Dens, the Buyer is their Prey.
The Knack of Trades is living on the Spoyl;
They boat, ev'n when each other they beguile.
Cutomes to teal is uch a trivial thing,
That 'tis their Charter, to defraud their King.
All hands unite of every jarring Sect;
They cheat the Country firt, and then infect.
They, for God's Caue their Monarch dare dethrone;
And they'll be ure to make his Caue their own.
VVhether the plotting Jeuite lay'd the plan
Of murth'ring Kings, or the French Puritan,
Our Sacrilegious Sects their Guids outgo;
And Kings and Kingly Pow'r wou'd murther too.
VVhat means their Trait'rous Combination les,
Too plain t' evade, too hameful to confes.
But Treaon is not own'd when tis decry'd;
Succesfull Crimes alone are jutify'd.
The Men, who no Conpiracy wou'd find,
VVho doubts, but had it taken, they had joyn'd.
Joyn'd, in a murual Cov'nant of defence;
At firt without, at lat againt their Prince.
If Soveraign Right by Soveraign Pow'r they can,
The ame bold Maxime holds in God and Man:
God were not afe, his Thunder cou'd they hun,
He hou'd be forc'd to crown another Son.
Thus, when the Heir was from the Vineyard thrown,

In vain to Sophitry they have recoure:
By proving theirs no Plot, they prove 'tis wore;
Unmask'd Rebellion, and audacious Force.
Which, though not Actual, yet all Eyes may ee
'Tis working, in the immediate Pow'r to be;

Firt to dilik, and after to depie
Then, Cyclop-like in humane Fleh to deal:

Perhaps not wholly to melt down the King:
But clip his regal Rights within the Ring.
From thence, t' aume the pow'r of Peace and VVar:
And eae him by degrees of publique Care.
Yet, to conult his Dignity and Fame,

And hold the Cards, while Commons play'd the game
For what can Pow'r give more than Food and Drink,
To live at eae, and not to be bound to think?
Thee are the cooler methods of their Crime;

Thus Out-laws open-Villany maintain:
They teal not, but in Squadrons coure the Plain,

Such impious Axiomes foolihly they how,

And though the Clymate, vex't with various winds

But thou the pander of the peoples hearts,
O Crooked Soul, and erpentine in arts.
VVhoe blandihments, a Loyal Land have whor'd,
And broke the Bonds he plighted to her Lord;
What Cures on thy blated Name will fall!
Which Age to Age their Legacy hall call;
For all mut cure the Woes rhat mut decend on all.
Religion thou hat none: rhy Mercury

Yet, hou'd thy Crimes ucced. hou'd lawles Pow'r

For thine, (if thou hat any,) mut be one

A jolly God, that paes hours too well

A Tyrant theirs; the Heav'n their Priethood paints

Without a Viion Poets can fore-how

And Crowds profane, with impious Arms prevail,
Not Thou nor thoe thy Factious Arts ingage
Shall reap that Harvet of Rebellious Rage,
With which thou flatter't thy decrept Age.
The welling Poyon of the ev'ral Sects.
Whlch wanting vent, the Nations Health infects
Shall burt its Bag; and fighting out their way
The various Venoms on each other prey
The Presbyter, puft up with piritual Pride,
Shall on the Necks of the lewd Nobles ride:
His Brethren damn, the Civil Pow'r defy;
And parcel out Republique Prelacy.
But hort hall be his Reign: his rigid Yoke
An Tyrant Pow'r will puny Sects provoke;
And Frogs and Toads, and all the Tadpole Train.
Will croak to Heav'n for help, from this devouring Crane.
The Cut-throat Sword and clamorous Gown hal jar,
In hareing their ill-gotten Spoiles of War:
Chiefs hal be grudg'd the part which they pretend;
Lords envy Lords, and Priends with every Friend
About their impious Merit hall contend.
The urly Commons hall repect deny;
And jutle Peerage out with Property.
Their Gen'ral either hal his Trut betray,
And force the Crowd to Arbitrary way;
Or they upecting his ambitious Aym.
In hate of Kings hall cat anew the Frame;
And thrut out Collatine that bore their Name.
Thus inborn Broyles the Factions wou'd ingage;
Or Wars of Exil'd Heirs, or Foreign Rage,
Till halting Vengeance overtook our Age:
And our wild labours, wearied into Ret,
Reclin'd us on a rightfull Monarch's Breat.
